description: From Scots claik, from Old Norse klaka.

entries.meaning: (Scotland) The cry of a goose, or other bird.

examples: you might hide with your lass on the top of Ben Nevis and have your bit pleasure there, but ten to one when you got up to go home there'd be Mistress Munro or some claik of her kidney, near sniggering herself daft with delight at your shame.

verbs.description: claik (third-person singular simple present claiks, present participle claiking, simple past and past participle claiked)

entries.meaning: (Scotland) To honk or cry like a goose.
